text: Team, another great reason to be mindful of huge images on site designs: Google  may add a 'slow' tag in search results. <http://www.webperformancetoday.com/2015/02/25/google-new-slow-label-web-performance/>

attachments.title: Google's experimental new "slow" label could revolutionize how we tackle web performance - Web Performance Today
attachments.text: Google is experimenting with a red "slow" label on search results pages. The label warns people that your site is unacceptably slow.
attachments.fallback: Web Performance Today: Google's experimental new "slow" label could revolutionize how we tackle web performance - Web Performance Today

text: A really fantastic read on designing for the web. <http://frankchimero.com/talks/the-webs-grain/transcript/>
Was gonna post this last night but never got past bookmarking it. Excited to read it!
"But, this contradiction is unavoidable and unsolvable, so the only choice is to recognize it as implicit to the medium, and devise strategies to manage it."
he draws a great parallel between responsive web design and David Hockneys joiner photographs

Once upon a time, there was a thread in here about onboarding screens for user account creation, and someone posted a cool example with several horizontal sliding screens. Anyone happen to have a link still kicking around?
then again, I could be completely imagining things....

Thanks for posting this <@U0260V1BX>. This essay hits close to home.

In the last months I've grown increasingly frustrated by a lot of the design I've seen online. Lots of "we want the web to behave like a slidedeck." Static, controllable (by us) and predictable (to us). Unfortunately, the web is the wrong medium for that. You could fake it. Make it behave like an iPhone app or a powerpoint but that comes with a high UX and usability cost to our users. Seems like a huge missed opportunity since that same effort could be used to make web products awesome by using its strengths and not weaknesses to differentiate a design. </rant>

The slide deck thing is super annoying, I agree, and i think a lot of companies are using that format specifically for analytics purposes or to annoy people into paying for a subscription. I was looking at an article (using that term generously)  about plants on Better Homes & Gardens and when i clicked on the "View all on one page" link, it put up a subscription wall. But yeah, it's not just publishers that are doing it.
